results.title: Headstart for Omar
results.creator_credit: Myrtle Winter-Chaumeny, United Nations Television and United Nations Relief and Works Agency for Palestine Refugees in the Near East
results.brief_description: Omar was a boy when he fled with his parents from the family orange grove near Jaffa and joined 750,000 Palastinian Arab refugees streaming out of the new State of Israel. Ever since then Omar has waited and now lives in Qatar, where he works and bides his time. Like others of 1948, Omar waits for the world community to settle a long overdue account.

results.title: Jeanette Powell
results.creator_credit: ACMI, Lisetta Moscardo and Helen Simondson
results.brief_description: In 1996 Powell became the first female to represent The Nationals in the Victorian Government when she was elected as the Member for the North Eastern Province in the Legislative Council. Powell’s political career began as a Councillor for the Shire of Shepparton. Powell has served as Shepparton Shire President, was appointed a commissioner with the Shire of Campaspe in 1994 and in 2002 Powell was elected as the State Member for Shepparton District. Powell is currently the Shadow Minister for Local Government and the Shadow Minister for Aboriginal Affairs.

results.title: A Half million teenagers
results.brief_description: Studies the physiology aspects of venereal disease. Uses animation to show how the organisms of gonorrhea and syphilis enter and affect the body and how the diseases may be recognised. Stresses the need for treatment, pointing out that there is a cure for both diseases.

results.title: Game Masters: Fumito Ueda interview
results.creator_credit: Roberto Salvatore, ACMI Content Development and ACMI
results.brief_description:
Fumito Ueda may have only two published games but each one has had such an impact that his influence is felt keenly across the industry. Ueda joined Sony Computer Entertainment in 1997 where he developed his first game, ‘ICO’ (2001), a beautifully poetic adventure game based on an abstracted boy-meets-girl premise. Ueda’s next game, ‘Shadow of the Colossus’ (2005) took an opposing theme to ICO’s sacrificial narrative, with the aim being to topple 16 giant mythical beings to restore the life of a girl named Mono.

NB: This interview was conducted in Fumito Ueda’s native language of Japanese and features English subtitles. Interviewer is neither seen nor heard onscreen.

results.title: Golden summers: the Heidelberg school
results.creator_credit: Peter Purvis, Peter Bramley and National Gallery of Victoria
results.brief_description: Golden Summers covers the most celebrated period in the history of Australian art, the years from 1885 until shortly after the turn of the century. The artists at the time were Tom Roberts, Arthur Streeton, Charles Conder and Fred McCubbin, popularly known as the Heidelberg School, and they believed that it was their task to paint Australian realities. Narrated by Patrick McCaughey.

results.title: Life is beautiful
results.brief_description:
Nga’s children have been her motivating force to search for a better life. Nga reflects upon her family’s journey of migration from Vietnam to Australia. She is proud of her achievements and the achievements of her children.
Made at ACMI as part of the ‘Recovering Hope’ Digital Storytelling project, in partnership with VicHealth and Belgium Street Neighbourhood House.

results.title: The Irrepressible Jack Stone
results.brief_description: A heartbreaking but inspiring story about Jack Stone, the kid who lived every moment of his life to the fullest - as told by his mother. Created as part of ‘The Heart of the Story’, an ACMI Digital Storytelling Project in association with the National Heart Foundation of Australia (Victorian Division) in partnership with VicHealth. You can create your won Digital Story. Ask at the Information Desk or go to www.acmi.net.au/digitalstorytelling

results.title: Passionate pursuits
results.brief_description: This story was created for Robin Hodder’s grandchildren to celebrate his extraordinary achievements as an Olympic sportsman, a husband of 38 years and the world’s greatest dad. Created as part of the ‘Memory’s Voice: Capturing Stories of Courage’ workshop, an ACMI Digital Storytelling Project in association with Alzheimer’s Australia Vic and in partnership with VicHealth.

group.title: Memory's voice: capturing stories of courage

results.title: The Dandenong Story
results.creator_credit: Geoffrey Thompson and Cine Service Productions
results.brief_description: Dandenong, Victoria, named after an Aboriginal tribe, is a fast growing town. As the gateway to Gippsland and the Latrobe Valley, it is important for agriculture. But even more significant is the development of big industrial plants manufacturing goods such as carpets, trucks, cars and fruit cans. Such decentralization of industry is bringing prosperity and a high standard of living to Dandenong and Australia as a whole.
